repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/2864

* No longer analyse annotations in FuncDef - the analysis was
not really used anyway, only typing was used
* Added helper code to help get sensible PyObjects when annotations
are Cython types
* A bit more testing (and removal of some tests that go against Python
behaviour)
* Block reanalysis of internals of `__annotations__` dictionary - I feel `AlreadyAnalysedNode` is a bit of a hack though, but I couldn't seem too many other options.

This seems to work although could probably do with a bit more testing that the annotations that come out are correct. It adds a new failure in `pep492_badsyntax_async2`. I'm not 100% sure what to do about this - I've never used the `async` syntax so I don't understand it. The code also doesn't seem to fail when run in Python3 (although I suspect it's nonsense) so I'm not sure how important the error is.

comment_data.body: While it's not been a strict requirement, we tend to assume in Cython that re-analysing an expression generally works, or at least doesn't break anything. Why is it necessary to prevent it here?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -13564,6 +13594,12 @@ def generate_result_code(self, code):
         code.put_gotref(self.result())
 
 
+class AlreadyAnalysedNode(ExprNode):
+    # Holds some already-analysed subexprs, which are not reanalysed but
+    # are just popped out. Built for "annotations_dict", which is constructed
+    # with its expressions having already been through analyse_types and thus
+    # couldn't be put through again

@@ -2242,6 +2242,14 @@ def visit_IndexNode(self, node):
         if node.is_fused_index and not node.type.is_error:
             node = node.base
         return node
+    
+    def visit_AlreadyAnalysedNode(self, node):
+        """Avoid going any further in analysing"""
+        subexprs = node.subexprs
+        if len(subexprs)==1:

comment_data.body: I wouldn't mind if all `FuncDefNode`s had a `return_type_annotation`, defaulting to `None`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -370,9 +370,18 @@ def exit_scope(self):
         self.env_stack.pop()
 
     def visit_FuncDefNode(self, node):
+        # note that "return_type_annotation" is only on subclasses
+        # FIXME just "return_type_annotation" or all outer_attrs?
+        attrs = [attr for attr in node.child_attrs if attr != "return_type_annotation"]
         self.enter_scope(node, node.local_scope)
-        self._process_children(node)
+        self._process_children(node, attrs)
+        outer_scope = self.current_env().outer_scope
         self.exit_scope()
+
+        if getattr(node, "return_type_annotation", None) is not None:

comment_data.body:
You only copied `self`, not `self.args`. Maybe you wanted the loop to be more like
`self.args = [arg.analyseâ€¦() for arg in self.args]` ?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -7377,6 +7405,13 @@ def analyse_types(self, env, skip_children=False):
         # not setting self.type here, subtypes do this
         return self
 
+    def analyse_as_possible_annotation_type(self, pos, env):
+        # work on a copy of self
+        self = copy.copy(self)
+        for i, arg in enumerate(self.args):
+            self.args[i] = arg.analyse_as_possible_annotation_type(pos, env)

comment_data.body: Why the "_possible_" ? The other functions just say "analyse_as_X()", even if it's not an "X".
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -655,6 +655,20 @@ def analyse_as_type(self, env):
         # type, return that type, else None.
         return None
 
+    def analyse_as_possible_annotation_type(self, pos, env):

comment_data.body:
The issue was that `CoerceToComplexNode` and `CoerceToBooleanNode` (and possibly some others) didn't have `analyse_types` so the re-analysis failed.

It sounds like it would be better to just give them an `analyse_types` that returns `self` (and now that I look some of the other `CoerceTo...` Nodes have that)? Shall i do that instead?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -13564,6 +13594,12 @@ def generate_result_code(self, code):
         code.put_gotref(self.result())
 
 
+class AlreadyAnalysedNode(ExprNode):
+    # Holds some already-analysed subexprs, which are not reanalysed but
+    # are just popped out. Built for "annotations_dict", which is constructed
+    # with its expressions having already been through analyse_types and thus
+    # couldn't be put through again

commit.message:
Fixed annotations with binding enabled

* No longer analyse annotations in FuncDef - the analysis was
not really used anyway, only typing was used
* Added helper code to help get sensible PyObjects when annotations
are Cython types
* A bit more testing (and removal of some tests that go against Python
behaviour)
* Block reanalysis of internals of __annotations__ dictionary
Fix scope and add tests for return type annotations

Fixed refnanny error on return_value_annotation

By following already-working example for regular annotations

title: Fixed annotations with binding enabled [fixes test `embedsignatures`]
